abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Land Administration
            Project for Ghana were as follows: outcome was moderately
            unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate;
            bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory; borrower
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Independent
            Evaluation Group (IEG) derives five lessons from the project
            that are of broad relevance to other operations of this
            nature: (i) attempts to 'harmonize' customary and
            statutory land tenure institutions will not be successful if
            the conflicts of interest over rent allocation are not
            addressed, and if priority is not given to distributing
            rents in accordance with the public good;(ii) land tenure
            reform calls for a long term commitment by the government
            and its development partners; this commitment may be
            facilitated by a programmatic lending instrument but the
            commitment must precede the choice of instrument the
            instrument by itself will not create the necessary
            commitment; (iii) the bank's annual doing business
            survey may give a misleading impression about trends in the
            efficiency of property registration services; (iv)although
            the bank's good practice guidelines indicate that the
            efficiency of land administration services tends to be
            higher when they are handled by a single agency, in
            practice, consolidating land agencies does not in itself
            ensure that their efficiency will improve; and (v) projects
            with multiple co-financiers are risky: if each insists on
            imposing its own procurement and disbursement procedures
            implementation may be delayed; and the strategic priorities
            of the partners may diverge in the course of project
            implementation, undermining support for achieving the
            project outcomes that were originally agreed to.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Land Administration
            Project (LAP) for Ghana were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            low, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: the key activities supported
            under LAP, ranging from merging and streamlining land
            agencies, systematic land titling and demarcation of
            customary boundaries to developing systems for resolving
            land conflicts, were merely laying the basis for a longer
            term engagement in reforming land administration. The
            success and sustainability of land reforms require a longer
            term perspective and support from development partners and
            other social actors to help the government overcome social
            and political inertia. Since the restructuring of the LAP
            and launching of LAP2, a longer-term perspective has been
            the key guide to planning and implementation. Donor
            commitment to long-term programs of land management and
            administration is essential to their success. The success of
            land projects and programs depends on long-term commitment,
            including a commitment to avoid the premature termination of disbursements.

repnme.cdata!:
Land policy : securing rights to reduce
            poverty and promote rural growth

abstracts.cdata!:
Modern, efficient, and transparent land
            administration systems are important in reducing poverty,
            and promoting growth and sustainable development. Security
            of property rights is central to preserving livelihoods,
            maintaining social stability, and increasing incentives for
            investment and for sustainable, productive land use. Making
            land rights transferable allows the landless to access land
            through sales and rental markets or through public
            transfers, and further increases investment incentives.
            Since the late 1960s, the World Bank has provided financing,
            technical help, and training to strengthen national land
            administration laws, policies, and investment programs.

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Land administration policy - To
            promote rural growth and reduce poverty

abstracts.cdata!:
This report on Land Policy, Securing the
            rights to reduce poverty and promote rural growth points out
            that modern systems of efficient and transparent land
            administration are important to reduce poverty and promote
            growth and sustainable development. It is essential to
            ensure the property rights to protect livelihoods, maintain
            social stability and increasing incentives for investment
            and for sustainable use and productive land. The report adds
            that since the late 60's, the World Bank provides
            financing, technical assistance and training to strengthen
            legislation, investment policies and programs on national
            land administration.

            ADMINISTRATION PROJECT - DISBURSING CHI
13281315.majtheme: Public sector governance,Environment and natural resource management,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives for the Land
            Administration Project for Ghana is to stimulate economic
            development, reduce poverty and promote social stability by
            improving security of land tenure, simplifying the process
            for accessing land and making it fair, transparent and
            efficient, developing the land market and fostering prudent
            land management. Reallocation is necessary to view the fact
            that certain critical activities must be completed before
            the project closes. The allocation of uncommitted funds, as
            of March 31st , 2010, showed that the budget for training
            and workshops as well as goods had been overdrawn and funds
            available for operating expenses were inadequate while there
            were more than enough funds for consultancies. This was
            largely due to modifications in the planned project
            activities after the initial restructuring which impacted
            significantly on operational expenses. The closing date of
            the project will be extended from December 31, 2010 until
            June 30, 2011. The extension of the closing date will also
            facilitate a smooth transition between phase one and two.

display_title.display_title:
Ghana - Land Administration
            Project : restructuring : Main report

13283413.trustfund:
BBFAO-BB FAO,TF026393-PHRD-GHANA: LAND ADMINISTRATION PROJECT,TF053449-Canadian International
            Development Agency (CIDA) Co-financing for Ghana,TF055576-CIDA COFINANCING FOR GHANA LAND
            ADMINISTRATION PROJECT - DISBURSING CHI

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives for the Land
            Administration Project for Ghana is to stimulate economic
            development, reduce poverty and promote social stability by
            improving security of land tenure, simplifying the process
            for accessing land and making it fair, transparent and
            efficient, developing the land market and fostering prudent
            land management. Reallocation is necessary to view the fact
            that certain critical activities must be completed before
            the project closes. The allocation of uncommitted funds, as
            of March 31st , 2010, showed that the budget for training
            and workshops as well as goods had been overdrawn and funds
            available for operating expenses were inadequate while there
            were more than enough funds for consultancies. This was
            largely due to modifications in the planned project
            activities after the initial restructuring which impacted
            significantly on operational expenses. The closing date of
            the project will be extended from December 31, 2010 until
            June 30, 2011. The extension of the closing date will also
            facilitate a smooth transition between phase one and two.

display_title.display_title:
Ghana - Land Administration
            Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet
